Authors:
Marla D. Schwarzfeld, Gavin R. Broad, Felix A.H.
Sperling
Title:
Preliminary phylogeny of the diverse parasitoid genus Ophion
Fabricius (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae, Ophioninae), based on 28S, COI,
and ITS2 DNA sequence data and ITS2 secondary structure
Abstract:
Ophion is a diverse genus of nocturnal Ichneumonidae that
is particularly species-rich in temperate areas, yet has received little
taxonomic attention in the Nearctic and Palearctic regions, where most
species occur. While there have been some attempts to divide Ophion into
monophyletic species groups, the vast majority of species have been
lumped into a single, paraphyletic group, the O. luteus species group,
which was defined only by the lack of characters specific to the other
groups. The challenging morphology of this large catch-all group has
limited attempts to subdivide it, and no phylogenetic hypothesis has
been proposed for the genus as a whole. In this study, we use DNA data
(28S, COI, and ITS2) to present the first molecular phylogeny of Ophion.
We also describe the secondary structure of ITS2 for the first time in
Ichneumonidae, and explore its implications for phylogeny estimation. We
define ten species groups, eight of which were previously considered
part of the O. luteus species group s. l.: the O. minutus, O. areolaris,
O. scutellaris, O. slossonae, O. parvulus, O. flavidus, ‘Species group
1’, O. luteus s. s., O. pteridis, and O. obscuratus species groups.
Additional sampling over a wider geographic range would provide further
insights into Ophion phylogeny, but this study provides a framework for
future studies of this diverse and morphologically challenging
genus.
